hints_html:
It suffices to consider the number modulo 1000.

Euler’s theorem will help.
hints_latex: It suffices to consider the number modulo 1000.
hints_raw:
It suffices to consider the number modulo 1000.
Euler's theorem will help.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
Since considering a number modulo 1000 gives the last 3 digits, it suffices to consider this number modulo 1000. Now

\(\displaystyle \phi(1000) = \phi(2^{3}\cdot5^{3}) = \phi(8)\phi(125) = (4)(100) = 400\)

Euler’s Theorem (valid throughout since \(\displaystyle \gcd(7,1000) = 1\)) states that

\(\displaystyle 7^{400} \equiv 7^{\phi(1000)} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}\)

and so we have

\[\begin{aligned} 7^{999} &\equiv 7^{400}\cdot 7^{400}\cdot 7^{199} \mod{1000}\\ &\equiv 7^{199} \mod{1000}\end{aligned}\]

Let’s examine \(\displaystyle 7^{200}\). Notice that

\(\displaystyle \phi(8) = 4 \quad \text{and} \quad \phi(125) = 100\)

and so by Euler’s Theorem, we have

\(\displaystyle 7^{200} \equiv (7^{4})^{50} \equiv 1 \mod{8}\).

Thus \(\displaystyle 7^{200} = 1 + 8s\) for some integer s. Further,

\(\displaystyle 1 + 8s \equiv 7^{200} \equiv (7^{100})^{2} \equiv 1 \mod{125}\)

and so \(\displaystyle 8s \equiv 0 \mod{125}\) giving \(\displaystyle s = 125t\) for some integer t. Thus, \(\displaystyle 7^{200} = 1 + 8s = 1 + 1000t\). So \(\displaystyle 7^{200} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}\). Hence

\(\displaystyle 7^{199} \equiv 7^{-1} \mod{1000}\).

To complete the proof, we need to find the inverse of 7 modulo 1000. We can do this via the Euclidean algorithm.

\[\begin{aligned} 1000 &= 7(142) + 6\\ 7 &= 6(1) + 1\end{aligned}\]

and back substituting gives

\[\begin{aligned} 1 &= 7 -6(1)\\ 1 &= 7 - (1000 - 7(142))(1)\\ 1 &= 7(143) -1000(1)\end{aligned}\]

and so the inverse of 7 modulo 1000 is 143. Hence

\(\displaystyle 7^{999} \equiv 7^{199} \equiv 7^{-1} \equiv 143 \mod{1000}\)

completing the question.
sols_latex:
Since considering a number modulo 1000 gives the last 3 digits, it
suffices to consider this number modulo 1000. Now

$\displaystyle \phi(1000) = \phi(2^{3}\cdot5^{3}) = \phi(8)\phi(125) = (4)(100) = 400$

Euler's Theorem (valid throughout since
$\displaystyle \gcd(7,1000) = 1$) states that

$\displaystyle 7^{400} \equiv 7^{\phi(1000)} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}$

and so we have

\begin{align*}
7^{999} &\equiv 7^{400}\cdot 7^{400}\cdot 7^{199} \mod{1000}\\
&\equiv 7^{199} \mod{1000}
\end{align*}

Let's examine $\displaystyle 7^{200}$. Notice that

$\displaystyle \phi(8) = 4 \quad \text{and} \quad \phi(125) = 100$

and so by Euler's Theorem, we have

$\displaystyle 7^{200} \equiv (7^{4})^{50} \equiv 1 \mod{8}$.

Thus $\displaystyle 7^{200} = 1 + 8s$ for some integer \emph{s}.
Further,

$\displaystyle 1 + 8s \equiv 7^{200} \equiv (7^{100})^{2} \equiv 1 \mod{125}$

and so $\displaystyle 8s \equiv 0 \mod{125}$ giving
$\displaystyle s = 125t$ for some integer \emph{t}. Thus,
$\displaystyle 7^{200} = 1 + 8s = 1 + 1000t$. So
$\displaystyle 7^{200} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}$. Hence

$\displaystyle 7^{199} \equiv 7^{-1} \mod{1000}$.

To complete the proof, we need to find the inverse of 7 modulo 1000. We
can do this via the Euclidean algorithm.

\begin{align*}
1000 &= 7(142) + 6\\
7 &= 6(1) + 1
\end{align*}

and back substituting gives

\begin{align*}
1 &= 7 -6(1)\\
1 &= 7 - (1000 - 7(142))(1)\\
1 &= 7(143) -1000(1)
\end{align*}

and so the inverse of 7 modulo 1000 is 143. Hence

$\displaystyle 7^{999} \equiv 7^{199} \equiv 7^{-1} \equiv 143 \mod{1000}$

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Since considering a number modulo 1000 gives the last 3 digits, it suffices to consider this number modulo 1000. Now

<math> \displaystyle \phi(1000) = \phi(2^{3}\cdot5^{3}) = \phi(8)\phi(125) = (4)(100) = 400</math>

Euler's Theorem (valid throughout since <math> \displaystyle \gcd(7,1000) = 1</math>) states that 

<math> \displaystyle 7^{400} \equiv 7^{\phi(1000)} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}</math>

and so we have

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
7^{999} &\equiv 7^{400}\cdot 7^{400}\cdot 7^{199} \mod{1000}\\
&\equiv 7^{199} \mod{1000}
\end{align}
</math>

Let's examine <math> \displaystyle 7^{200}</math>. Notice that 

<math> \displaystyle \phi(8) = 4 \quad \text{and} \quad \phi(125) = 100</math>

and so by Euler's Theorem, we have

<math> \displaystyle 7^{200} \equiv (7^{4})^{50} \equiv 1 \mod{8}</math>.

Thus <math> \displaystyle 7^{200} = 1 + 8s</math> for some integer ''s''. Further,

<math> \displaystyle 1 + 8s \equiv 7^{200} \equiv (7^{100})^{2} \equiv 1 \mod{125}</math>

and so <math> \displaystyle 8s \equiv 0 \mod{125}</math> giving  <math> \displaystyle s = 125t</math> for some integer ''t''. Thus, <math> \displaystyle 7^{200} = 1 + 8s = 1 + 1000t</math>. So <math> \displaystyle 7^{200} \equiv 1 \mod{1000}</math>. Hence

<math> \displaystyle 7^{199} \equiv 7^{-1} \mod{1000}</math>.

To complete the proof, we need to find the inverse of 7 modulo 1000. We can do this via the Euclidean algorithm.

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
1000 &= 7(142) + 6\\
7 &= 6(1) + 1
\end{align}
</math>

and back substituting gives 

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
1 &= 7 -6(1)\\
1 &= 7 - (1000 - 7(142))(1)\\
1 &= 7(143) -1000(1)
\end{align}
</math>

and so the inverse of 7 modulo 1000 is 143. Hence 

<math> \displaystyle 7^{999} \equiv 7^{199} \equiv 7^{-1} \equiv 143 \mod{1000}</math>

completing the question.
statement_html: Find the last three decimal digits of the number \(\displaystyle 7^{999}\).
statement_latex:
Find the last three decimal digits of the number
$\displaystyle 7^{999}$.
statement_raw: Find the last three decimal digits of the number <math> \displaystyle 7^{999}</math>.
